text: This miniature landscape encompasses a lot of what I focused on during my PhD.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So obviously it does this in a literal way, since my work has centered on microbes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But as we'll see, and I'm sure many of you know, the microscopic world is teeming with incredibly complex relationships.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's why I also like to think of this picture in sort of a figurative sense, since what my work aims to do is find a way to navigate these complex landscapes, if you will.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what I'll try to do in this talk is sort of go through some work I've done over the past few years, which I hope will also paint a picture into my own journey into complexity research.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So to start with the basics, why, I guess, do we even care about microbes in the first place, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What could possibly be so complex about them?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You might find yourself asking.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And for me, it's a little easier to get a grasp on their impact just by thinking about how long they've been around.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this right here is a geological summary of life on Earth, which I think is a really simple but kind of great tool for putting this into perspective.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So microbes have been around for around 80% of Earth's history.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Whereas we have only been around for 0.004% of that time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So they've been here for a really long time and had a lot of impact in shaping what the planet looks like currently.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And they continue to do a lot of stuff.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So they're integral to the cycling of nutrients in the soil and in the oceans.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And they're really important to our own health where we have learned
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: more and more how the trillions of microbial cells associated with the human body are crucial to things ranging from digestive processes to immune regulation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I guess all of this is to say that we very much live in a microbial world and it's therefore really important to understand the different types of things that these organisms are doing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Different types of microbes, I should say, don't just live on their own.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: As many of you probably know, if we zoom in on any one of these ecosystems, we would obviously see that they live together with a bunch of different species making up microbial communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And as such, the types of microbes that make up a community and what they're doing is really important.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So a classic example of this is in the intestinal microbiota, where a certain composition of microbes can be associated with a healthy gut, whereas a different composition of microbes can be associated with an inflamed or diseased state.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this question of who's there in terms of the microbes that are present is really important for the health of an ecosystem.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in recent years,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We have been able to address this question of who's there in a variety of biomes, like in oceans around the world, in soil ecosystems, and on a bunch of different sites of the human body.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But knowing the composition of a community is only part of the story.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So knowing what the microbes are doing and how they're working together or interacting in these ecosystems is also really crucial.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So then how do we describe these microbial interactions?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Well, for example, if we have two microbes and one is making a particular molecule for another, we can call this commensalism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If the other is reciprocating with a different molecule, we can call it mutualism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And both of these would be examples of cooperation, but organisms can obviously also compete for particular nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And these outcomes can let us classify interactions in different ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But this framing is still fairly simplistic and definitely has its limitations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for one, looking at interactions only in terms of their cooperative or competitive outcome starts to become very difficult when you have a large number of species.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So as an example, this right here is a correlation network that we can use to infer interactions in the human oral microbiome.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: where every node here is a particular microbial genus.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for complex communities like the ones we encounter in nature, understanding how all of these interactions take shape can be a really challenging task.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I think this is encompassed really nicely by this, which is one of my favorite tweets, which says, let's not think about more than two microbes interacting at a time and everything will be okay.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And even to add more complexity to this, it's not just that communities can contain hundreds of interacting species, but also that these interactions themselves depend on a bunch of different factors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So how the organisms are arranged in space impacts how they exchange nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There are, for example, bioluminescent bacteria in squid that glow based on the day-night cycle, so temporally dependent interactions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It can be metabolically costly for the organisms to produce exchange molecules.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then other factors such as pH, nutrient availability, and the temperature of the environment can all influence how these microbes interact and therefore what the community will look and behave like.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I guess all of this is to say that interactions are these complex and multidimensional phenomena.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this complexity makes them hard to study.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But the ability to know what they're doing will let us harness them to do a bunch of really helpful things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is what's called, I guess, the new field of synthetic ecology, where people try to engineer new microbial communities for applications in health and the environment, among other things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: just to throw off a few examples um there's a number of companies right now making microbiome therapeutics um we're starting to understand how the microbiome modulates our immune response uh and some applications have even reached clinical trials such as uh this development of treatments for uh for crohn's disease and outside the area of human health
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: These microbial communities are relevant to the production of new biofuels, can be engineered to clean up oil spills.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And finally, there's a lot of work that has been going on to make microbiome treatments to increase crop yield and make them more resilient to disease and environmental pressures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But I guess in order to reach this promise, a lot more work definitely has to be done to make sense of the complexity of microbial interactions, as well as all of the different factors that I mentioned that can influence communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this will bring us to the first topic that I'll discuss today, which deals with a framework that we designed to kind of help us make sense of the different factors that influence these microbial interactions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So as we now know, high throughput technologies, like for example, 16S sequencing, metagenomics, metabolomics, have allowed us to learn a lot of what's going on in microbial communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And of course, the vast majority of these studies focus just on a single biological system or experimental setup, which lets us look really deeply into those specific conditions, but limits our ability to compare interactions across different studies and infer larger scale patterns.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And having this ability would let us start tackling really big ecological questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: For example, are certain kinds of interactions more prevalent in certain taxa?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or even how common is mutualism across all biomes?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we need, I guess, is a way to somehow integrate all this data on interactions that we've been collecting so we can systematically compare different examples.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I guess how could we start doing this?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Well, a common way to look at interactions, as I mentioned before, is by placing them somewhere along this cooperation competition axis.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But of course, as we already noticed, interactions are really diverse and can depend on a bunch of different factors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And they encode much more information than just whether or not they were cooperative or competitive.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what I did early on in my PhD was this sort of thought experiment where we asked, can we come up with some kind of standard way to represent interactions while still embracing all of these attributes?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what we came up with was a simple list of nine basic attributes that we could use to describe interactions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So these ranged from whether or not the interaction depended on a particular spatial arrangement of microbes, for example, to whether the compounds involved were something like peptides to the habitat in which that interaction was observed.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we could now do with this is represent any particular interaction numerically, according to whether or not it displayed a certain attribute.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So with this framework in mind, what we did was we compiled a list of interactions that we sourced from the literature and manually classified them according to all these different attributes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in the end, we can think of each interaction sort of as an entry in a catalog, which has its own sort of numerical barcode, if you will, defined by the presence or absence of these attributes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And as simple as this sounds, what this let us start doing was starting to perform these basic analyses to look now at how often certain attributes or interaction types were observed and how similar or dissimilar different interactions were with some surprising results there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and and what we really look forward to with this is that kind of as new high throughput data sets continue to get generated they can be compiled in some similar way or it can be easier to compile them in this way for us to tackle these much bigger ecological questions so
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: With this, I would point out that this is by no means a new idea in general.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So standardized formats have been designed for metabolic networks, such as KEGG, if you're familiar with that, as well as for protein sequences or protein interaction networks and 16S sequences.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we hope that by sort of applying these ideas to this world of microbial interactions, we can start doing the kinds of analyses and predictive studies that these other methods enabled.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I very much invite you to sort of look at our perspective piece here for more details on what we did.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But with this, I'd like to transition over to the second part of my talk, which will look much more deeply into one of these interaction attributes, which is the question of metabolic cost.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I'll get to what that means in a second, but just to give a little bit of background,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I would start by saying that there's this tenet in classical ecology called the competitive exclusion principle, which basically says that two populations that completely compete for a certain niche cannot coexist.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what this means is that if you have two microbes and both are competing for the same food source, the one that is less efficient at consuming it will die out.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It will be out-competed by the other one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The problem is that this leads to a concept called the paradox of the plankton, which asks, how then is it that we see so many organisms coexisting in nature when there seem to be so few resource niches?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And there's many strategies that can help us address this question, but the one we were interested in was that of metabolic cooperation or cross-feeding.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this happens when one organism produces a molecule that feeds the other, and that allows both of them to survive.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The problem with crossfeeding is that oftentimes for the organism to produce that molecule, it needs to devote away some of its own resources and sacrifice its own biomass production.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this then can lead to the emergence of what we call cheaters in a community who only receive these benefits without putting anything back.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it raises kind of really big questions as to how this selfless cooperation can emerge in the first place.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So there's been a lot of studies that have looked into the costs and benefits of this kind of cross feeding.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But we wanted to ask, what would happen if we sort of took this question of cost completely out of the equation?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So essentially, can we look at molecules that can be secreted without an organism sacrificing its own growth?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: which is a pretty big question, which kind of raises the question of how we would even measure this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we decided to do was use a computational technique called flux balance analysis, or FBA.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And to use FBA, what we do is we get a model of a particular organism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is done by taking the genes and metabolic pathways that we know are part of a particular species,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we use them to build what's essentially a mathematical representation of all of the metabolic capabilities of an organism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So with this model, we then apply flux balance analysis, or FBA, which is a mathematical optimization technique that pretty much asks the following.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it says, given a particular organism's metabolic capabilities and given a particular environment, how fast is that organism going to grow?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So at what rate will it produce biomass?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And importantly to us, which metabolites is it going to produce?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And does producing them impact the growth of the organism?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what's nice about this method is that we can ask these questions very precisely for any organism for which we have this kind of model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So now that we have a way to know when a particular metabolite is secreted in this quote-unquote costless way, we can ask, okay, which molecule specifically can be secreted like this?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We know that organisms produce metabolic byproducts all the time, like ethanol as a byproduct of sugar fermentation, for example, but how far does this really extend across a large number of microbial species and environments?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And moreover, are these molecules enough to allow other organisms to grow?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or are they essentially just waste products?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If they do allow other organisms to grow, what interactions could we see emerging from these?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And importantly, how stable are these interactions over time?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the way we went about answering these questions is by doing a large set of computational simulations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in each one of these simulations, we took two organisms, provided them with a growth medium, which contained two different carbon sources, two different nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we can also choose whether or not to provide oxygen to the organisms, which becomes important down the line.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: With this in mind, we apply flux balance analysis and see, first of all, whether or not the organisms grew.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if they did, which metabolites did they secrete in this costless way into the environment?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what we can then do is add these molecules back into the medium and feed it back to the organism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in this way, we're essentially carrying out an in silico co-culture experiment where the organisms can feed off of each other's metabolic byproducts.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the really cool thing about doing this with FBA is that since we, in this study, did it using a list of 24 organisms, 108 different carbon sources, with and without oxygen, we were able to sort of examine the impact of these costless metabolites in over 2 million simulated experimental conditions, which I think for anyone would be almost impossible to do experimentally, at least with current techniques.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: With this method, now we can go back to our question, which types of molecules can be secreted in this, quote unquote, costless way?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we immediately noticed was that, as I hinted at before, the presence of oxygen really was one of the biggest modulators of this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we go into much greater detail on this in paper, which I'll mention in a bit.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But as an overview, we do see kind of a wide diversity of molecules ranging from organic acids, as we expected, but also nucleic acids and peptides and even some more complex molecules.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So now that we know kind of what types of molecules can be secreted, we can then ask our next question, is the presence of these molecules enough to allow other organisms to grow?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And here, looking at kind of the core data set that we generated, we can say that many times it is.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what these bars are is they represent the total number of simulations that were performed.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And because these media conditions that we provided only contained two carbon sources, the majority of the cases fell into this light blue section, which means that either only one organism grew or neither of the organisms grew.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But what's really interesting, what we want to point out is this red set of simulations in the middle, which tells us that at the start of our simulation, only one organism grew, but the metabolites that it secreted were enough to allow the other organism to grow as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This sort of enhanced growth potential represented by the red region represents a 73% increase in the growth supporting environments with oxygen and an 83% increase in those without oxygen.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that was exciting just to see that these secretions can kind of lead to the growth of other organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what's nice is that we can look at these cases a little bit more deeply on an organism by organism basis to get kind of a detailed picture of which organisms are the ones that are enabling the growth of others.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what we found were these sort of rich networks of these obligate interspecies interactions that show how, for example, this methylobacterium organism depends strongly on E. coli, or how in a lot of these interactions, the salmonella organism is the one providing nutrients to all the others.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what I'd like to note here is that these organisms that we picked don't normally appear together in nature.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But what this does provide us with is sort of a jumping off point to study any one of these particular symbioses experimentally.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I'd point out as well that although these were generated with FBA, we were able to corroborate a number of these by comparing them to specific examples from our lab and also from the literature.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: uh so kind of building upon these interspecies interactions what our data set let us do was kind of zoom out and get an idea of the different types of interactions that emerge from these costless secretions so we saw very clearly that even though organisms can be competing for primary nutrients they can also be cooperating on the level of these metabolic byproducts
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we could see how often we got certain types of interactions like commensal unidirectional ones or these mutualistic bidirectional ones.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And very importantly as well, there wasn't just one type of commensalism or mutualism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what our data set that let us do then is zoom in a little more and look at the exact interaction topologies that emerged.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we did this using a network motif approach, which you can see represented here, where the big yellow circles in each one of these motifs is an organism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The black dots are carbon sources and the purple dots are any metabolites that might be exchanged between the two.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And these motifs ranged from really simple ones like non-interaction to unidirectional commensal ones, which we abbreviated with C to more complex mutualistic bidirectional ones that we abbreviated with M. And what these motifs let us do
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: is design dynamical equations to predict how the organisms would grow over time under these conditions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I'd say this is a very important distinction since what FBA does is essentially just give you a snapshot of what the organisms are doing at one point in time, whereas here now we could really ask how stable these different interaction types could be over longer periods of time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So just to go over this very briefly, we made differential equation models for each one of these interaction topologies and parameterized them using the FBA data that we got.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we let the organisms grow in a sort of simulated continuous culture environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we asked was if both organisms survived at the end of these simulations, I guess that would let us know a reasonable idea of whether or not these specific motifs were stable under the conditions that we set.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is kind of a broad representation of the results, which I'll take you through.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we did in these simulations was we modulated the growth rates of organism one on the x-axis and organism two on the y-axis.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the areas in red within these areas in black that you see are showing the combinations of parameters that allow for coexistence of the two organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So by doing that, we can see that, for example, this simple interaction N1A, there's no combination of growth rates that lets both organisms survive, which is trivial since obviously here organism two isn't receiving anything at all.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it doesn't have any food.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's not going to grow.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The next motif is this sort of classic competitive exclusion where the species will only coexist if the growth rates of the two organisms are pretty much identical.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So again, that makes sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But then if we start having more complex interactions, we start to see some pretty interesting things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for instance, this mutualistic motif, M1b, even though the organisms are competing for a primary resource,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: the metabolic exchange is enough to sort of sustain them for a pretty wide parameter space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what this study really lets us do is say, okay, well, we have these costless metabolites that we looked at in this huge sampling of organisms and environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then these metabolites can spontaneously lead to the emergence of certain interactions that allow other organisms to grow.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it also let us have an idea of how stable these different interactions could be.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And as I kind of alluded to before, in doing this analysis, we produced a really big data set of kind of very specific metabolically driven symbioses, which we can follow up on on a case by case basis.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this in itself can be really useful to this idea of synthetic ecology that I mentioned at the beginning, which kind of if we have a better idea of how microbes interact in this way, we can leverage that knowledge to engineer new interactions for a number of applications.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So at this point now, we've looked at how one of these interaction attributes that we identified at the beginning, this idea of metabolic cost can shape microbial ecosystems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I'll continue with the next section, which looks at another attribute in more detail.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And here we're gonna look at environmental composition and how specifically environmental complexity impacts the structure and function of these microbial communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what does this mean?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: One of the findings from our last study, which was really important, was that the composition of the environment, so literally the nutrients that the organisms have access to, was actually more important than the identity of the organisms themselves in determining which molecules would be secreted.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And given how consequential we determined the secretions and these interactions to be, it sort of adds to this body of evidence saying that molecular composition of the environment has a really important impact on what a community will look like.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But there's a problem in sort of trying to understand this question of environmental composition since
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: natural environments can contain thousands of different nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The result of this is that we see a lot of studies of communities in very simple environments where we can get a lot of deep insight into the biology, as well as a lot of studies that take natural samples, but oftentimes just tell us the species composition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Bridging this gap is definitely really important.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we do know from isolated or from specific studies that the complexity of an environment is very important in a general sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So there have been studies that have shown how, for example, the gut microbiomes of people under simpler Western diets are really different to those under kind of more complex hunter-gatherer diets.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this concept is also important in lakes and oceans where an overabundance of one particular nutrient can cause these algal blooms that can destroy entire ecosystems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we want to know here is how do microbial community properties scale with increasing environmental complexity, so with a more diverse pool of nutrients?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And right now I'll tell you about the portion of our study that looked into the impact on this environmental complexity on taxonomic diversity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we focused on studying this systematically in a well-controlled experimental system in the wet lab so that we could really focus specifically on the effects of sort of a different number of nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we did was we started with a number of bacterial organisms and we cultured them all separately overnight.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And after that, we combined them all in equal proportions and added them to these culture plates, which contain a minimal medium and an assortment of different carbon sources.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So either single carbon sources or more complex combinations of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we varied the number of different carbon sources, but we always kept the concentration the same.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we did was we then grew these communities in all of these conditions and transferred them to fresh medium conditions so the communities would reach steady state.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And depending on how complex the community was to begin with, we measured what the taxonomic compositions looked like, either using auger replating or 16S sequencing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in total, this experiment allowed us to look at the effects of this environmental complexity on over 280 different communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And right now, I'll go into detail on the results of one particular experiment where we tested a community that contained 13 species in combinations of up to 32 carbon sources that we assayed using 16S sequencing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But before I get into the results, let's just look kind of very briefly at what we would maybe expect to see.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if we're basing ourselves again on classical ecological theory, so specifically niche partitioning and competitive exclusion, we might expect that the more complex an environment is, the more taxonomically diverse a community grown in it might be.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But we know now from some new experiments on computational work that this might not always be true.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for example, we have evidence that when two nutrients are combined, the community can exhibit sort of a nonlinear growth response.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we know from work done by former grad student in our lab that even single carbon source environments can sustain very, very biodiverse communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Lastly, we have evidence in an animal model that high nutrient diversity might not even be associated with high microbiome biodiversity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This relationship between environmental complexity and community diversity is definitely more complex than I thought at the beginning of this project.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: With that kind of background, let's come back to our experiment and see what we get.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: These are the relative abundances of our communities under each condition we tested.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The different environments are here on the x-axis, and the bars represent the breakdown of the different organisms that were observed at the end of these experiments in those different environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Generally, as we move to the right, the environments become more complex.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Here are the communities grown in single carbon sources.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Here are the ones grown on pairs, on combinations of four carbon sources, eight, 16, and then the one community grown on all 32 carbon sources.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: so right off the bat we can see that there are varying degrees of taxonomic diversity but what we see is is that a lot of these communities are just dominated by a couple of organisms and in fact none of the communities here retained all of the original 13 organisms that we put in
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So to find out what happened, we can start by only looking at the communities grown on the single carbon sources.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what we could do is kind of take these taxonomic distributions and compare them to how the organisms grew on their own, so not in a community, on these same nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And by doing this, we can see, for example, that this organism, Acinetobacter balei here, was able to grow on glutamine by itself.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it was also observed in the community, grown on glutamine.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's what these navy blue squares are.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Alternatively, you can see that this Corynebacterium glutamicum couldn't metabolize glutamine on its own.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's on the top left.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it also didn't show up in the community.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But interestingly, we see that this space is dominated by sort of this light blue, which means that although an organism was observed to use a particular nutrient on its own, when you put it in a community setting, it disappears.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what this indicates is that interspecies competition, so competition for these resources and not just environmental selection is a major factor in these losses in taxonomic diversity that we saw.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Interestingly, though, I'd point out that there were a few cases where the opposite thing happened.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So, for example, by itself, the Pseudomonas futita in our experiments wasn't able to metabolize ribose, but it did show up when we placed it in a community context.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this could be an example of one of the cooperative cross-feeding interactions that we were really excited to see.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So going back to our full results, now we can look at what happens to the diversity of these communities as we increase the complexity of the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we can look specifically at the species richness, which is defined as just the number of different species that we observed.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we see, for example, that in the 32 nutrient case, we get four unique bacterial species.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What was surprising initially was that there were even some single nutrient cases where we saw up to six different species, which was the most out of any condition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, as a different metric of diversity, we can look at this quantity called the Shannon entropy, which sort of defines how
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: taxonomically balanced a community is and here as well we see that some single and even some double and quadruple nutrient conditions are more taxonomically balanced than even our most complex environment so as a result neither of these relationships showed a statistically significant increase with environmental complexity
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we sort of found ourselves asking ourselves, what could be going on?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Well, one of the things we noticed was that a couple of organisms showed up consistently in our communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And when we look back at how they grew in monoculture, so by themselves, we can see that they had some of the broadest nutrient utilization capabilities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in essence, they were resource generalists.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They could use a lot of different things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So maybe we thought it's something to do with who is a generalist and who is a specialist that determines the types of organisms that persist in a community and not just the number of the raw number of nutrients that we put in.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So to quantify this, what we did was we designed a dynamical model called the consumer resource model, which predicts the abundances of different organisms based on how well they can use a particular nutrient.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So essentially, it gives us a way to define who is more of a generalist, who is more of a specialist, and then what the communities will look like with different balances of the two.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what's nice as well is it lets us look at what types of metabolic interactions can go on.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we parameterize this model using our experiments, as well as some flux balance predictions for metabolic exchange.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we use this to make two models.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So model A, in which all of the organisms have the same chance of consuming certain nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And consumer resource model B, in which you have a breakdown of generalists and specialists that are similar to the communities we tested experimentally.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what's nice about the model is that we can simulate these many, many times with randomly assigned nutrient utilization probabilities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we're not just limited to the specific experimental conditions we tested.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So here again, in a different format, are our species richness and Shannon entropy values from the experiment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And let's compare them to the first modeling results.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this model tells us we should expect higher diversity than what we actually saw.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And again, here, you only have specialists.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the likelihood that the organisms might overlap in terms of niches is lower.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But now looking at what happens when we have a mix, we see a much stronger agreements with our experimental results in which we see much lower levels of taxonomic diversity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this was striking and it was really nice to see since these models were pretty much parameterized based on nutrient utilization capabilities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we're able to kind of very nicely reflect what we saw experimentally.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So overall, what do these results mean?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Well, it suggests that kind of contrary to this classical intuition, environmental complexity is not a requirement for maintenance of taxonomic diversity in microbial communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we know that now by having done this sort of systematic study of how the same community responds to increasingly complex environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This gave us an idea of the strong role that competition plays in dampening the diversity of these communities with some instances of metabolic cooperation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we found that what appears to be most important in determining the composition is, of course, the identities of the nutrients, but also the distribution of generalist and specialist organisms within these communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And another important thing that we gained, again, just like the last study, is this rich data set that correlates specific environmental compositions to community compositions and also their growth phenotypes, which I couldn't get into today.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I think we can use data sets like these as jumping off points to sort of design complex communities, again, by modulating their environments.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So there's a lot more that we did, and I invite you to look at our preprint up on the archive for this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This article is actually now in press, so hopefully you should see it out very, very soon.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But very quickly, I want to move to our last section,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: where I'll briefly talk about some work that now leverages what we've learned in order to design new synthetic communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what for me has really come out of this work is sort of a deep appreciation for how even small changes in environmental composition can give you very, very different community structures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So part of that is really scary, but part of that is exciting since it sort of gives us a chance to ask the reverse.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if I want a community with a certain structure or certain behavior, is there an environmental composition that can get me there?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this idea is really attractive since modifying the environment is often a lot easier to do than modifying the genes inside the organisms themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what this puts forward is the possibility of sort of rational environmental modification as another design tool for this field of synthetic ecology.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The problem, as you might have guessed, is that there are just so many possible combinations of environmental nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So for example, if you wanted to test all combinations of 20 nutrients, which is an amount that's far lower than what we would expect in nature, you would need to do around 1.05 million experiments, so not very accessible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And even if you wanted to rely solely on modeling, just slightly increasing the complexity of these environments would very quickly get you to quantities that are computationally intractable.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we need a way to search the space of possible nutrient combinations to get us to a specific community composition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And there's a lot of methods that can help us do this, but the one we ended up choosing was a simple genetic algorithm.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what this is, for those of you unfamiliar, is just a search process based on natural selection, which works as follows in our case.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So first, we randomly initialize different environments with different nutrients.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We grow our communities on them and see how they perform.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So these are just sample growth curves.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And say here we wanted the most taxonomically balanced community.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we could rank the environments based on how close they got us to that goal.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we would pull the top ones to produce a new generation of environmental conditions based off of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We can also allow for some random mutations to happen.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So those are the little red squares that you can see in order to fully explore this combinatorial space.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we can then take these environmental conditions and test them again, refining them over and over, over the course of several generations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what should happen is that over time, the process should converge to an optimal set of environmental conditions for the goal that you had in mind.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So now what we can do is take our community and our environments, grow them up,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: measure how the community did in the context of the objective that we want to optimize, and run it through this algorithm to help us select the new set of environmental conditions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what we did here was, since we don't have the experimental data set to be able to do this fully, we relied on simulated community data, again, relying on flux balance analysis.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So very, very quickly, just to kind of end, I'll show you some of the things that we can do with this.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So let's say we have a multi-species community and we want to make it as taxonomically diverse as possible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we can set, again, the Shannon entropy as the objective and have the algorithm find us environments that maximize it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So here we can see that for this community, the maximum Shannon entropy is around 2.5 and the algorithm is able to get us there within just 20 generations or iterations of this cycle.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if we wanted to have a community that was dominated by a particular organism, we could do that as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if we wanted to maximize the number of metabolic exchanges, it can find environments to do that.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we tested a bunch of different objectives in addition to these.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what's powerful about pairing this with flux balance modeling is that for any of these solutions, we can go more deeply into the metabolic networks to see which interactions and exchange patterns are going on that can lead to these particular community phenotypes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I realize that I've thrown a lot at you, so I'll stop here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So just to review this part, what we've been able to do is combine sort of a search algorithm with flux balance modeling that gives us environmental compositions that are likely to give us community structures that we want.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, of course, here we tested it on computational data, which has its limitations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So first and foremost, is the question of accuracy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So even the best genome scale models are bound to have prediction errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And even though in this study, we only used manually curated high quality models, we can't be sure that they'll necessarily give us the right answer.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is why we designed this framework with the intent of integrating with an experimental system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So a nice thing about the genetic algorithm is that you can test a reasonable amount of experimental conditions at a time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we envision a setup whereby you do an experiment, feed the data into the algorithm, and it suggests new compositions to try.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And with the advent of new sort of ultra high throughput technologies, you could imagine sort of the sci-fi future where this is all automated and you get your target community through this kind of combined computational experimental process.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So just to review what my work really focused on and what I talked about today was first looking at how complex microbial interactions could be and starting by kind of proposing a framework that embraces all of this complexity, all this heterogeneity to enable ways to quantitatively analyze and compare these interactions across different studies.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We looked at how this question of metabolic cost, one of the attributes that we defined
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In our review article, we could define what a microbial interaction looks like.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And from here, noticing that the composition of the environment was a crucial determinant of these interactions, we looked specifically at this underexplained question of how the complexity of the environment itself contributes to community ecology.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then based on what we learned here, we designed an evolutionary algorithm that can let us design new microbial communities with specific structures just by modifying the environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in sum, what I hope this work does is shed light on the mechanisms that underlie microbial interactions with a specific focus on how the environment affects them.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And what I find really exciting is that
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: it gets us closer to being able to rationally design communities via environmental modification.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And definitely, hopefully, shows how a combination of experiments and modeling can help us eventually achieve these promises that I mentioned of synthetic ecology.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So with that, just take a quick moment to thank the people who supported this work.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So a lot of this, or all of this, rather, was done under the supervision of my advisor, Daniel Segre.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I'd also like to thank my dissertation committee and members of the lab, both past and present, for all of their support.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Also thanks to my collaborators and people who gave me advice through all of this, as well as obviously the bioinformatics program at BU, and for the funding sources that made this work possible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And before ending, I would just like to give a shameless plug for another super cool funding source, which is the
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: James S McDonald postdoc fellowship in understanding dynamic and multi-scale systems so they are currently funding my postdoc research and the application for the 2021 cohort just opened up pretty recently so I have to say this is an awesome funding opportunity for anyone looking to do research after their PhD not just in the area of biology but in all areas of
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: complexity research.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I would say check them out at their Twitter handle or feel free to reach out to me directly if you have questions about the fellowship or the application process.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So with that, thank you for taking the time to listen.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Thank you for the invitation again to join me today.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I'll stop now for questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Wow.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Really fantastic talk.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Thank you, Alan.
speaker: SPEAKER_01
